column1: 2015M&PS...50.1449S|2015|Exploring the Moon's surface for remnants of the lunar mantle 1. Dunite xenoliths in mare basalts. A crustal or mantle origin?|Shearer
column10: Clive R.|Meteoritics and Planetary Science|50|8|1449|Remotely sensed observations from recent missions (e.g.
column13: Chandrayaan-1) have been interpreted as indicating that the deep crust and upper mantle are close to or at the lunar surface in many large impact basins (e.g.
column17: the capability of either impact or volcanic processes to transport mantle lithologies to the lunar surface should be enhanced in these regions. Somewhat problematic to these observations and interpretations is that examples of mantle lithologies in the lunar sample collection (Apollo Program
column19: lunar meteorites) are at best ambiguous. Dunite xenoliths in high-Ti mare basalt 74275 are one of these ambiguous examples. In this high-Ti mare basalt
column20: olivine occurs in three generations: olivine associated with dunite xenoliths
column22: and olivine microphenocrysts. The dunite xenoliths are anhedral in shape and are generally greater than 800 μm in diameter. The interior of the xenoliths are fairly homogeneous with regard to many divalent cations. For example
column23: the Mg# (Mg/Mg + Fe × 100) ranges from 82 to 83 in their interiors and decreases from 82 to 68 over the 10-30 μm wide outer rim. Titanium and phosphorus X-ray maps of the xenolith illustrate that these slow diffusing elements preserve primary cumulate zoning textures. These textures indicate that the xenoliths consist of many individual olivine grains approximately 150-200 μm in diameter with low Ti
column25: and P cores. These highly incompatible elements are enriched in the outer Fe-rich rims of the xenoliths and slightly enriched in the rims of the individual olivine grains. Highly compatible elements in olivine such as Ni exhibit a decrease in the rim surrounding the xenolith
column26: an increase in the incompatible element depleted cores of the individual olivine grains
column27: and a slight decrease in the "interior rims" of the individual olivine grains. Inferred melt composition
column29: and zoning profiles enable the reconstruction of the petrogenesis of the dunite xenoliths. Preservation of primary magmatic zoning (Ti
column31: Al) and lack of textures similar to high-pressure mineral assemblages exhibited by the Mg-suite (Shearer et al. 2015) indicate that these xenoliths do not represent deep crustal or shallow mantle lithologies. Further
column32: they are chemically and mineralogically distinct from Mg-suite dunites identified from the Apollo 17 site. More likely
column33: they represent olivine cumulates that crystallized from a low-Ti mare basalt at intermediate to shallow crustal levels. The parent basalt to the dunite xenolith lithology was more primitive than low-Ti basalts thus far returned from the Moon. Furthermore
column34: this parental magma and its more evolved daughter magmas are not represented in the basalt sample suite returned from the Taurus-Littrow Valley by the Apollo 17 mission. The dunite xenolith records several episodes of crystallization and re-equilibration. During the last episode of re-equilibration
column35: the dunite cumulate was sampled by the 74275 high-Ti basalt and transported over a period of 30-70 days to the lunar surface.

The sharp decrease near the surface identifies for the first time production of <SUP>41</SUP>Ca by solar cosmic rays. column2: John|Journal of Geophysical Research|92|B4|E349|The evolution of the major element compositions of mare basaltic liquids and coexisting crystals in low-pressure fractionation processes has been modeled in order to examine the postulated link between picritic volcanic glasses and mare basalts. column4: 1982] have been modified to include expressions for the Cr-spinel liquidus surface and the boundary between the armalcolite and ilmenite surfaces; average molar partition coefficients for armalcolite/liquid pairs are also included in the modifications. Results of the calculations show that most mare basalts are not derived by simple low-pressure fractionation from parents with the compositions of picritic glasses as tabulated by Delano [1986a]. Also
column5: there is no indirect evidence as yet for posteruption fractionation of picritic magmas in the form of sufficiently magnesian
column6: mare-type olivines at the Apollo 12 and 15 landing sites. However
column7: the calculations do suggest that Luna 24 ferrobasalt and Apollo 11 high-K basalts could have been derived by simple
column8: near-surface fractionation of known picritic compositions. Also
column9: xenocrystic olivines with mare-like concentrations of TiO<SUB>2</SUB> and CaO in high-Ti basalt 74275 provide evidence for the existence of a picritic magma at the Apollo 17 site. More importantly
column10: the calculations indicate that the picritic magmas would have fractionated to produce basalts with bulk and mineral compositions generally similar to those of mare basalts. These latter results favor the hypothesis that mare basalts have fractionated
column11: “nonprimary” compositions and that the small number of observed linkages between basalts and picritic parents is a consequence of limited sampling.

column4: L. A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||117|Lunar armaloclites
column7: contain appreciable amounts of Ti(3+) (less than 1 to 17% of Ti mole fraction). This is a function of the oxygen fugacity occurring at the time of its formation
column8: with lower fugacities being reflected in higher Ti(3+) contents. Controlled cooling-rate and isothermal experimentation on synthetic analog and natural specimens of 70017 and 74275 have been used to calibrate an oxygen geobarometer. Most lunar rocks have followed crystallization paths in oxygen fugacity/T space such that the prevailing oxygen fugacity can be represented by a curve near parallel to the I/W buffer curve. The oxygen fugacity estimates derived from Ti(3+) considerations of armalcolites range from the iron/wustite curve to about 1.5 log units below.

column1: 1978LPSC....9..601I|1978|Experimental partitioning of rare earth elements and scandium among armalcolite
column8: D. E.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||601|An experimental study was carried out to measure partition coefficients for two rare-earth elements (Sm and Tm) and Sc among armalcolite
column10: olivine and liquid coexisting in a system modeled on high-Ti mare basalt 74275. This 'primitive' sample was chosen for study because its major and trace element chemistry as well as its equilibrium phase relations at atmospheric pressure are known from previous studies. Beta-track analytical techniques were used so that partition coefficients could be measured in an environment whose bulk trace element composition is similar to that of the natural basalt. Partition coefficients for Cr and Mn were determined in the same experiments by microprobe analysis. The only equilibrium partial melting model appears to be one in which ilmenite is initially present in the source region but is consumed by melting before segregation of the high-Ti mare basalt liquid from the residue.
